bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to James E. Peabody, September 22, 1928

div1.p: Kean responds to Peabody's questions about the work of the Yellow Fever Commission, offering his view on the contributions of various men and commenting on illustrations Peabody has selected for his article.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to James E. Peabody, September 22, 1928
div1.opener:
Army Medical Museum,
Seventh and B Streets S. W.
Washington, D. C.
22 September, 1928.
Prof. James E. Peabody,
The Morris High School,
New York City.
My dear Prof. Peabody:
div1.p:
Your letter has just come with the galley of the illustrations
of your article. That figure 14 is certainly no joke on me, because
have not and never had the remotest connection with it. People who
like practical jokes might think it a joke on Gorgas because it is
certainly is a most unflattering picture of him, but it is he all
right. I will lokk up a picture as soon as I go home and send it to
you. I will try to find you one of those days when I was a Major.
As you have three pictures of Kissinger and one of Jernegan, why don't
you have a picture of Moran who was the real hero of that bunch, the
man who volunteered at the same time with Kissinger, who always re-
fused to accept any gratuity and has always shown a fine spirit of
dignity and independence. I think we can probably scrape up a pic-
ture of him if you want it. His present address is John J. Moran,
Emprado 22, Habana, Cuba.

I do not think there are any points of dispute between Reed's
friends and Gorgas'. Mr. Hendrick who collaborated with Mrs. Gorgas
on their biography of him made some absurd claims of credit to Gorgas
which belonged to Reed but I have direct information that this was
done quite contrary to Mrs. Gorgas' wishes and belief. I understand
that he cut out what she wrote and put in his own stuff because he
thought it made a better story. Also I don't think there is any con-
troversy between the friends of Finlay and Carter. I never heard of
any. As to Agramonte and Noguchi, there is no longer any controversy.
Agramonte was right all along, and Noguchi's friends and companions
now all admit that he was in error.

You ask waht Agramonte did on the Commission. It was fully as im-
portant as Carroll's or Lazear's. In the first investigations of the
Board which cleared the field. Carroll had the bacteriological work,
Agramonte the autopsy work and gross pathology, and Lazear the micro-
scopical pathology. When the mosquito work was taken up, Lazear had
charge of the mosquitoes as he had previous training with mosquito work
when studying malaria in Italy. Agramonte conducted the autopsies
and studied the pathological anatomy. Carroll continued to do the bac-
teriological work. After Lazear's death, Agramonte took charge of the
Mosquitoes and for a while when Carroll was ill and recuperating from
his attack of yellow fever and Reed was absent in the United States,
he had charge of everything. Agramonte and Lazear were classmates in
Columbia University Medical School, and he is a fine man. I am sure
that no Congressman will vote against the bill for the inclusion of
his name. I explained the importance of recognizing his work fully to
the Military Committee at their hearing last soring.

You ask why the Cubans do not honor Agramonte. I think they do but
it is a little hobby of theirs to soft pedal the work of the Reed Board
and give as much credit as possible to Finlay. gramonte received a
great ovation at the medical meeting in New Orleans and was given a
medal for his contributions to the victory of the Reed Board over yel-
low fever.

I don't see any objection to your labelling figure 24 “germs that
Dr. Noguchi thought caused yellow fever” but some of his friends may
feel differently about this advertising of an error which he told for
with his life. Why don't you ask Dr. F. F. Russell of the Rockefeller
Foundation? He was devoted to Noguchi and was also one of our most
distinguished army surgeons. I think it would be well to add to your
label the statement that “the true germ has never been discovered.”

When you see Col. Wainwright I hope you will hearted him up. He
seemed quite discouraged the last time General Ireland and I talked
to him on the subject.

Yes, Reed's first announcement of his demonstration of the car-
rying of yellow fever by the mosquito was made before the 28th. An-
nual Meeting of the American Public Health Association at Indianap-
olis, October 22-26, 1900, where he read a paper entitled “The
Etiology of Yellow Fever-- preliminary Notes” His next paper in
which cation was fully set forth, together with the
means for preventing yellow fever by waging war on th mosquito, was
read at the Pan-American Medical Congress, Habana, Cuba, February 4-7
1901.

You are certainly wonderfully energetic in carrying on this work
and getting hold of influential people. I am sure that you would hav
no difficulty in having a few minutes talk with the Secretary of War
if he is in Washington when you are here.

I will goak to the Curator of the Museum and see if he will make
a photograph of the model of Camp Lazear and make a photostat copy of
the agreement between Major Reed (not General Wood) and the Spanish
immigrant Antonio Benino (sweet potatoes).
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, J. R. Kean,
Colonel, U. S. Army, Ret. -----
